What is the Earth like three centuries after an attempted alien invasion? One answer is Soro no Woto.
Background:  About three centuries before the show opens Earth had a high technological civilization, including partial negation of gravity. Earth was attacked by giant winged aliens. Either the aliens were driven off at great cost to the planet, or the war so devastated the planet that the aliens decided it was no longer worth conquering. In any event they are no longer around, save for a skeleton beneath a river, and much of the Earth is now a wasteland. 
Present Day: Humans have reformed civilization but mostlyat an early 20th century level. These new nations which rose from the ruins of the world tend to fight over what remnants of arable land and resources that still exist. Kanata, our main character, comes from a poor rural family. She joins the army and is assigned to the Unit which is comprised of our characters for the story, the 1121st Tank Platoon. Their assignment is to watch for any enemy activity from their remote post overlooking a wasteland at their far-flung end of the border. Its a good place to go to hide, to forget or to just get away from everything. All the Unit members Kanata meets have different issues/demons they are avoiding from their past (one of the more severe is PTSD from watching her friends burn to death in a tank). Kanata’s arrival is like a catalyst dropped into a beaker of solution: her bright, accepting personality touch each comrade in turn, and each in turn is then able to take a new view of their past and be uniquely redeemed from the largest regret in their own life. 


I find quite a lot happening in this anime, much of it growing in the background and then suddenly popping into the foreground of the story. One of my favorite aspects is that the girls are operating an illegal still and selling brandy on the black market because their Army pay is never on time! There are hints at this through several episodes and then it is brought to the forefront and becomes the focus for the plot of one episode. 


What do I like about this show? There's the characters, growing tensions with the neighboring kingdom, depictions of daily soldier life and training, issues with the mafia, challenges with getting an ancient high technology tank back into operating condition, and all backed up by good music and displayed on gorgeous scenery. This is also one of the rare anime that gets a soldier's life right.


I initially thought the script writer was talking about forgiveness for his chief theme, but he wasn't: he is talking about redemption, something more precious than forgiveness; and so Amazing Grace is the perfect recurring theme. 


There is quite a lot to this show, and I encourage everyone to give it a try.

I have to say that I really wanted to enjoy this anime, and I dd for about the first six episodes, but after that I began to lose interest. I have a few little complaints here and there but overall the show was quite good. What killed it in the end for me are two things; the first being that it became extremely boring as nothing ever really happened, and the second being that it seemed as if the anime wasn't really going anywhere.
Story (6/10)
This was my biggest issue with the anime, as I said, the story didn't really seem to be going anywhere. Ihad watched about 9 episodes before deciding to drop the anime. I was hoping that by 3/4s of the anime, the story would be in full swing, but nothing really ever happened. Through the show it seemed like a couple minor events would occur, but they would never seem to play a role on the reset of the show. I also was expecting a music anime, with the main character getting progressively better at the trumpet. However, the music could have been removed with minimal impact on the show. The music aspect was more of a minor backdrop to hold things together. My last issue on the story is that it takes place in the future, but the only indication of that is the tank which is very cyberpunk. The timeline just didn't make much sense. Ho could ALL modern technology be completely lost in a large war? How can there be these massive tanks with hologram screens, but no communications, they need trumpet players to send messages to each other? Again, the show could have just as easily been set during WW2 and very little would have changed, except for the fact that the time would make sense, then.


Art (7/10)

I'm going to keep this short and say that  the art is definitely good, but nothing more. I liked the way the characters and environment were drawn, but they weren't really anything special.


Sound (7/10)

I was really hoping for a good soundtrack here, but was really disappointing. There is really only one song through the whole anime, amazing grace. Other than that, the ambient music and sound effects were just...decent, nothing special. I really wanted to hear more interesting music coming from the anime. 


Character(6/10)

I enjoyed the main character. She was cheerful and energetic, but that is hardly anything new to an anime character. On top of that, she had absolutely no character development. At no point did she change or realize something aside from when she magically realized how to play trumpet well by watching glass being made...somehow. All of the other characters are rather flat as well. However, with their backstories, there was HUGE missed opportunity. The best example is when you learn one of the girls has PTSD from the war, but that is only relevant in that episode; after the episode, it is never mentioned again.


Enjoyment(6/10)

To keep this short I'll just say that the show started really strong for about five episodes, then slows down really hard by episode seven, then I lost interest by episode nine. The best way to some it up is by saying so little actually happens that it becomes a very boring show rather quickly.


So in the end, I wasn't a very big fan of Sora No Woto. I found the story and a lot of events to be really confusing, and the anime is really slow. It just wasn't my kind of anime, I suppose. I o recommend this anime to anyone who wants a simple story with little thinking, it is a very casual watch. It s nice and peaceful so it's a good one to relax to. With that said, if you are expecting a great story with engaging characters, I would refer you elsewhere.

Sora no Woto tells a charming and unique tale of five girls in the military. It takes slice-of-life and sets it in the middle of a post-apocalyptic war and the result is a truly well written and touching story.
A first impression of this anime would be “K-On + Military”. It’s not hard to assume this; the art style is very similar to K-On, and the cast is composed of five girls with traits that seem very similar to the five girls from K-On. 
Story: 9
As a slice of life, most of the episodes have rather slow and simple plots. Some of them are light-hearted andenjoyable, but still develop the characters brilliant and are relaxing to watch.  Others, especially the ones that develop the characters’ back story, have a much darker tone. Each episode also takes care into establishing the world that the story is set, as well as the town’s culture.  Near the end things take a far more serious tone, focusing on the war between Helvetia and Rome.  


Art: 10


The beautiful background art illustrates the charming town of Seize perfectly. The scenes are extremely detailed, and help to capture the calming mood of the series. Other times, the background shifts tone and instead portrays the horrors of war. The art style of the characters is similar to K-On, which I don’t really have a problem with. 


Sound: 10


The hymn, Amazing Grace, plays an important part in the story of Sora no Woto. Also important are the various bugle tunes played throughout the story. The background music is equally good, mostly composed of calming pieces to illustrate the mood of the series. A standout is "Servente du Feu" a sojng sung in French that is absolutely brilliant. The opening, Hikari no Senritsu by Kalafina, is beautiful as well. However, the ending is rather generic J-Pop, and doesn’t fit the series very well.


Character: 10


The characters seem to be cookie cutter moe stereotypes at first, but they actually have great, developed personalities. While the characters still “fit” into their stereotypes, they also have many other aspects to their personalities that are explored very well. The side characters are also well developed, and every character has their own unique charm.


Enjoyment: 10


This show is mostly very calming and has a very relaxing effect with the simple but enjoyable plots and great art and music. The times when it becomes more serious are also enjoyable as well. 


Overall: 10


Charming plot, well developed characters, beautiful music, and a unique and detailed setting. What’s not to like?

This is my first review, and I have something to say first.  First no anime is bad, it is just whether you enjoy it or not and second sometimes you have to look at things in other's perspective.  Also excuse my bad English.  
In my opinion, a great anime doesn't necessarily mean an anime is beautiful.  Here, So Ra No Wo To (Sound of the Sky) really presented itself as a beautiful piece of work, despite the fact the story is kind of rushed and the series should be longer and all the other stuff people criticize this piece about.To judge an anime, you should not judge it in your perspective, but rather look at the anime's perspective.  I'll explain what this means later.  


At first it is the name of this Anime which caught me in the eye, and all I have to say that all the aspects of So Ra No Wo To supported the name.  


The setting of the story gives you a feeling of a place of loneliness, it is set in place bordering No Man's Land which involves around the daily lives of those 5 girls in the army.  The phrase "the world is ending" is a recurring motif in the story, but despite the fact No Man's Land is expanding and possible ending of the world, the 5 girls proved it wrong.  The world can be ending, but the happiness they shared and their friendship will last forever.  Before I said you have to look at the anime's perspective, here's what i meant: it is true the story is kind of rushed and should've make it longer.  But if you look at the anime's perspective, it is 12 episodes, you can't fit everything in.  You have to rush somethings.  Even though it is not perfect, but it still done a good job from the limitations.  


There's nothing much I want to talk about art, it is good and it fits the story and setting well.  


Well the sound is amazing after all the story is evolve around sound.  And in my opinion, the sound really made this piece of work lively.  After the series, I truly changed my opinion of sound.  Even though war is dark and cruel, with sound, music it can bring peace.  The idea seems naive, but sometimes we have to be naive to understand each other.  This piece of work had created another world in me filled with beautiful sound.  


Character designs are moe, too cute to be in military and war, unrealistic.  This is anime after all, though its unrealistic, the designs changed the mood of anime.  Despite the fact they are in place where pay cannot be reached on time, their laugh, actions and encounter made the story seems to set in a totally different place.  


As I said, different people have different field of interest.  Even if you dont enjoy this anime, doesn't necessarily mean the anime is bad.  You shouldn't ruin other people's expectations and let them to decide whether it is good or not.  This anime brought me great enjoyment, because not often there are anime with a peaceful, slice of life background that have great music and artwork.  When watching, I enjoyed the comedy and their peace which deeply planted within my heart.  


Overall, this anime is great, it brings hope, and peace to people watching it.  Possibly it can also change your world perspective and understand the joy brought by sound.

This is a greatly subjective review, that being said - a 10 is quite warranted.
I have watched anime all my life, not really an anime fan of sort. It's just that it's a normal thing here in my country. Even adults watch Dragon Ball Z here. In any case that means that I have watched plenty of it, plus all the other media I consume. My point is, it is rare to see something so well executed. Especially the last episode (out of the special 13th episode) where it all coalesced into a beautifully told story. I have watched a few musical animes, but thisfor me seems to be the best to tell how music can break barriers down.


There are no idols here, no lolis, just 5 women in a small town. That might sound boring on paper, but so does music.


This is a gem of an anime, has the same feel as Mushishi and to an extent - the same pace. The action is there to remove monotony and is peppered in enjoyable doses. It is of course, not perfect. Pacing could have been just a tad faster but still. It knows it will get twelve episodes and it never overreaches. I just hope they make a sequel about the old world. 


Seriously though, listen to the story at the festival in the first episode. It will make everything in the twelfth episode so much more intense.


This is a gem and should be watched at least once in your life. :)

Since I'm a musician I always give a try to those animes based on music themes, and this one is no exception, and maybe the best... music itself gives a lead to the storyline, that connects the characters, 5 girls who live in a kind of forgotten military outpost in the mountains...
The past and the present are mixed up through the sound of the bugle, legend and history have their own melodies in their every day life, which is a quite simple routine, although very emotional... 
The art concept is warm and clean, the story as well as the environment  have an attractive mood,characters are compelling with strong personalities and the sound, oh the sound... it goes on with you after you see every episode... good music is always powerful...\n
this is a very unique anime...\n
enjoy...

So Ra No Wo To stood out to be one of my favorite anime. In spite of being short, it was up to the point with its story and message.
  The setting of So Ra No Wo To, although vague, is rather diverse and fleshed out. It does not tell you much on what happened to the world, or how things became the way that it is, but it does a good job at giving you hints and nods on those factors in a very efficient manner. This pretty much adds to the theme of the series as a whole, and leavesfor a lot to be explored, in a good way. 


 The characters, much like the setting, are very fleshed out as well. Not much is known about them, but from the few times their pasts get mentioned, it's enough to make them interesting and/or sympathetic. Their diverse personalities also adds to that, as well as make them more likeable as the series goes on. Just like the setting, it also ties in perfectly to the theme that this series is portraying. 


 Speaking of the theme, the story does a perfect job at portraying it through the dramedy contained in the series. It knows when to transition from lighthearted and quirky, to dreary and somber, and vice-versa without tampering with the setting and characters. With that in place, it makes the theme of the series that much stronger, especially towards the end. 


 The animation is also outstanding to look at, making it feel like you are actually there. The same thing goes for the soundtrack, which is gorgeous to listen to. Relying a lot on acoustic and orchestral music, it goes perfectly with the setting and tone that the series is portraying. Along with the great sound design, they succeed at immersing you into the setting with flying colors.


  Overall, this series is definitely worth watching. Interesting setting, great characters, great story, great production value, and especially the theme makes this series a masterpiece in my opinion. I highly recommend you watch it.

My first impression: it's like a better _K-On_, set in a _Ghibli_-esque army. This turns out to be fairly accurate as far as it goes, but as I kept watching the next 2 episodes of _Sora no Woto_, I was struck even more by all the borrowings from other series. The already mentioned _K-On!_ bits, but then there's Sasaki from _Azumanga Daioh_, opening art copying _Elfen Lied_, the character Noël being the old Rei/Yuki ripoff, Kureha is just annoyingly tsundere (or is she instead a nod to a Class S subgenre character like one from _Marimite_? Couldn't watch it, so dunno.) And I was flabbergastedthat in a post-apocalyptic nuclear war devastated medieval setting, the animators *still* managed to work in a ghost hunt in the school at night story! I await with interest and horror the cultural festival episode, the hot springs episode, the beach episode... ...And the onsen episode of _Sora no Woto_ was episode 5. I was only joking, animators, I didn't actually expect you to do it! It becomes better than it has any right to be for a good chunk of the series. And in particular, the backgrounds remained beautiful to the end. But unfortunately, the ending episode demonstrates why you can't cross _K-On!_ with _Now and Then, Here and There_ unless you are really good - it just comes off as a little bit silly.\n
